greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of representations of n as a sum of distinct tribonacci numbers (A000073).
comment: It can be shown that, like the Fibonacci numbers, the tribonacci numbers are complete; that is, a(n)>0 for all n. There is always a representation, free of three consecutive tribonacci numbers, which is analogous to the Zeckendorf representation of Fibonacci numbers. See A003726.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Math World: Tribonacci Number
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Math World: Zeckendorf Representation
mathematica: tr={1,2,4,7,13,24,44,81,149}; len=tr[[ -1]]; cnt=Table[0,{len}]; Do[v=IntegerDigits[k,2,Length[tr]]; s=Dot[tr,v]; If[s<=len, cnt[[s]]++ ], {k,2^(Length[tr])-1}]; cnt
program: p (k:ks) m = if m < k then 0 else p ks (m - k) + p ks m
xref: Cf. A000119 (number of representations of n as a sum of distinct Fibonacci numbers).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_ and _Jonathan Vos Post_, Mar 28 2006
ext: a(0)=1 added and offset changed by _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 13 2014
